questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
The LCD screen of a laptop computer emitted plane-polarized light. (A plane-polarized light wave always vibrates along the same axis [for example, up and down]). A special filter was placed in front of the computer screen. Light from the screen passed through the filter and struck a light sensor that was attached to a voltmeter, producing a voltage, V (see Figure 1). As the angular position, θ, of the filter varied, V varied.

A graph of V, in volts, versus θ, in degrees, is shown in Figure 2. Figure 3 shows the relationship between V and the filtered light's intensity, I, in lux.
questions.question: 1.  Based on Figure 2, at θ = 380°, V would most likely be closest to which of the following?

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:

As the angular position, θ, of the filter varied, V varied.

A graph of V, in volts, versus θ, in degrees, is shown in Figure 2. Figure 3 shows the relationship between V and the filtered light's intensity, I, in lux.
questions.question: 2.  In Figure 2, the change in V was greatest across which of the following intervals of θ ?

questions.question: 3.  Based on Figures 2 and 3, for which of the following values of θ would I be closest to 18 lux?

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article: Precipitation events and drought affect a stream's discharge (rate of flow) at a given time. The discharges of 3 streams (Streams 1-3) in the same drainage basin were recorded continuously over a 10-year period ending in 2002. Figures 1, 2, and 3 show the daily average discharge of Streams 1, 2, and 3, respectively, for a 3-month period of drought during 2002. In addition, Figure 1 shows the maximum and minimum daily discharges of Stream 1 during the 3-month period in 2002. Each figure also shows the historical daily average discharge of the respective stream, obtained by averaging the daily average discharge for the same 3-month period over the 10 years. Table 1 shows the area drained by each stream.
questions.question: 6.  A precipitation event in a drainage basin is followed within 2 days by a rapid increase in a stream's daily average discharge. Given this information and Figure 3, the largest precipitation event most likely occurred in the area drained by Stream 3 during which of the following weeks in 2002 ?

choices.A: For nearly all of the dates, the daily average discharge was less than the corresponding historical daily average discharge.
choices.B: For nearly all of the dates, the daily average discharge was greater than the corresponding historical daily average discharge.
choices.C: For approximately half of the dates, the daily average discharge was less than the corresponding historical daily average discharge.
choices.D: For approximately half of the dates, the daily average discharge was greater than the corresponding historical daily average discharge.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
Researchers studied how wildfire smoke affects the germination of Yellow Whispering Bell seeds.

Study 1

Seeds were collected from the plants. Some of the seeds were divided into 9 groups of equal numbers of seeds. The first group of seeds was placed, untreated, on moist, untreated filter paper for germination. Two other groups were treated by exposing them to wildfire smoke, one group for 1 min and one group for 10 min, prior to placement on moist, untreated filter paper for germination. Each of the remaining 6 groups was placed for germination on or in either moist sand, moist filter paper, or water, each of which had been previously treated by exposing it to wildfire smoke for either 1 min or 10 min. The percent of seeds from each group that germinated over the next 2 days is shown in Figure 1.

(Note: All smoke-treated materials were directly exposed to equal concentrations of smoke per unit time.)

Study 2

Study 1 was repeated with more of the collected seeds, except that the treated materials were directly exposed to NO2 gas (a component of wildfire smoke) instead of wildfire smoke for either 1 min or 5 min. The NO2 concentration per unit time was the same as that of the wildfire smoke in Study 1 (see Figure 2).


Study 3

Another group of the collected seeds was exposed in air for 10 min. Other groups of the collected seeds were directly exposed to different gases of various concentrations in air for various lengths of time. Each group was then placed on moist, untreated filter paper for germination (see Table 1).
questions.question: 11.  Which of the following was most likely used as the control in Study 3 ?

questions.question: 12.  Suppose, in Study 3, another group of the collected seeds had been exposed to NO2 at a concentration of 675 mg/m3 for 1 min. Based on the results of Study 3, the germination percent for that group of seeds would most likely have been:

choices.C: NO2 gas with a concentration of 790 mg/m3 in air
choices.D: N2O gas with a concentration of 15,300 mg/m3 in air

questions.question: 16. When NO2 gas contacts water, some NO2 gradually dissolves and lowers the water's pH. Given this information, which of the following is most consistent with the result in Study 2 for untreated seeds in water exposed to NO2 for 5 min as compared to 1 min ? The water became:

choices.A: more acidic, preventing the germination of most of the seeds in the sample.
choices.B: less acidic, preventing the germination of most of the seeds in the sample.
choices.C: more acidic, ensuring the germination of all of the seeds in the sample.
choices.D: less acidic, ensuring the germination of all of the seeds in the sample.

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
In high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), a sample solution is injected into a continuous flow of solvent, which carries the sample through a column packed with an adsorbent (see Figure 1).


The components of the sample separate from each other in the column. As each component passes through the detector, a peak is plotted on a graph. The portion (fraction) of solvent containing each component of the sample can then be collected and analyzed. The retention time (RT) is the time it takes for half of the component to pass through the column (the time that corresponds to the top of the peak).

Two experiments were done to analyze foods for the presence of sugars (which have the suffix "ose") and sugar alcohols (which have the suffix "itol"）

Experiment 1

A 0.01 mL sample of a solution containing 1 g/L each of several sugars and sugar alcohols was injected into the HPLC apparatus. The flow rate (FR) of solvent through the apparatus was 1.5 mL/min. The detector readings were plotted, and the fraction corresponding to each peak was collected and analyzed to determine its composition. The procedure was repeated at different FRs (see Figure 2).

Experiment 2

For each of 7 foods, a 1 g sample was mixed with 500 mL of ethanol in a blender, then stored overnight. Each mixture was filtered and then diluted to 1.000 L with ethanol. A 0.01 mL sample of this solution was analyzed by HPLC at FR = 0. 5 mL/min (see Table 1).
questions.question: 17.  In Experiment 1, at FR=1.0 mL/min, the RT of maltose was closest to which of the following?

choices.A: Sucrose, because it had the shortest RT.
choices.B: Sucrose, because it had the longest RT.
choices.C: Sorbitol, because it had the shortest RT.
choices.D: Sorbitol, because it had the longest RT.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Sorted circles (soil mounds 1-3 m wide bordered with rocks) are common in arctic regions (see Figure 1).


Two different processes combine to create sorted circles. Convection is the movement of water and soil due to temperature and density differences. When the water in the soil thaws and approaches 4°C, it sinks, forcing the 0°C water underneath upward. This lifts the soil surface and creates the soil mounds, as shown in Figure 2. Rocks that are on the surface roll down into the depressions and form the rock borders.

This convection is not capable of bringing rocks to the surface. Rocks are brought to the soil surface by frost heaving. Each time the temperature of the soil decreases to 0℃, the water around the top of rocks in the soil freezed first, pulling the rocks up with it. Fine clay particles fill in the space beneath so that the rocks end up in a slightly higher position than where they began.

Study 1

During spring thaw, a geologist moved rocks from the sorted circle's border to the center of the surface of the soil mound. By the next winter, the rocks had moved back to the border, and the frozen soil at the center of the surface of the mound was slightly higher than it had been during the thaw.

Study 2

A geologist observed the surface of a liquid that was being heated from below (see Figure 3). In the lighted areas, liquid was rising, and in the darker areas, liquid was sinking. It was noted that the liquid's surface resembled the group of sorted circles when viewed from above.

Study 3

A geologist buried a rock at a known depth in a container of damp soil. After the soil in the container had been frozen and thawed 4 times, the rock was 3 cm above its original position.

Figures adapted from Stefi Weisburd, "Halos of Stone." ©1985 by Science Service, Inc.
questions.question: 23.  Which of the following factors was purposely varied by the geologist during Study 3 ?

A geologist observed the surface of a liquid that was being heated from below (see Figure 3). In the lighted areas, liquid was rising, and in the darker areas, liquid was sinking. It was noted that the liquid's surface resembled the group of sorted circles when viewed from above.

Study 3

A geologist buried a rock at a known depth in a container of damp soil. After the soil in the container had been frozen and thawed 4 times, the rock was 3 cm above its original position.

Figures adapted from Stefi Weisburd, "Halos of Stone." ©1985 by Science Service, Inc.
questions.question: 24.  Which of the following statements best describes the relative densities of the rising liquid and sinking liquid shown in Figure 3 ?

choices.A: The rising liquid has the same density as that of the sinking liquid.
choices.B: The rising liquid has a lower density than that of the sinking liquid.
choices.C: The rising liquid has a higher density than that of the sinking liquid.
choices.D: In some of the areas, the rising liquid has a higher density than that of the sinking liquid. In otherareas, the rising liquid has a lower density than that of the sinking liquid.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Sorted circles (soil mounds 1-3 m wide bordered with rocks) are common in arctic regions (see Figure 1).


Two different processes combine to create sorted circles. Convection is the movement of water and soil due to temperature and density differences. When the water in the soil thaws and approaches 4°C, it sinks, forcing the 0°C water underneath upward. This lifts the soil surface and creates the soil mounds, as shown in Figure 2. Rocks that are on the surface roll down into the depressions and form the rock borders.

This convection is not capable of bringing rocks to the surface. Rocks are brought to the soil surface by frost heaving. Each time the temperature of the soil decreases to 0℃, the water around the top of rocks in the soil freezed first, pulling the rocks up with it. Fine clay particles fill in the space beneath so that the rocks end up in a slightly higher position than where they began.

Study 1

During spring thaw, a geologist moved rocks from the sorted circle's border to the center of the surface of the soil mound. By the next winter, the rocks had moved back to the border, and the frozen soil at the center of the surface of the mound was slightly higher than it had been during the thaw.

Study 2

A geologist observed the surface of a liquid that was being heated from below (see Figure 3). In the lighted areas, liquid was rising, and in the darker areas, liquid was sinking. It was noted that the liquid's surface resembled the group of sorted circles when viewed from above.

Study 3

A geologist buried a rock at a known depth in a container of damp soil. After the soil in the container had been frozen and thawed 4 times, the rock was 3 cm above its original position.

Figures adapted from Stefi Weisburd, "Halos of Stone." ©1985 by Science Service, Inc.
questions.question: 25.  Given the information provided, what kind of rock or soil movement, if any, would take place in winter, during the time when the ground is completely frozen for many months?

choices.A: Little or no rock or soil movement would take place.
choices.B: Convection would take place very rapidly.
choices.C: Rocks from the borders would mix with mound soil.

questions.question: 26.  Suppose that in Study 3, all the water had been removed from the soil before the soil was cooled to 0℃ and then warmed to above 0°C 4 times. A measurement of the buried rock's position after the 4 cooling and warming cycles were complete would most likely show that the rock had:

choices.A: moved up more than 3 cm from its original position above the bottom of the container.
choices.B: not moved up measurably from its original position above the bottom of the container.
choices.C: moved horizontally to the side of the container.
choices.D: sunk to the bottom of the container.

questions.question: 27.  The hypothesis that the rocks now on the surface were once buried in the soil in the mounds is supported by the results of which of the 3 studies, if any?

questions.question: 28.  Based on the information provided, convection in the soil beneath sorted circles is most likely the result of which of the following?

choices.B: Soil at 20°C has the same density as soil at 10°C.
choices.C: Moist soil is less dense than dry soil.
choices.D: Water at 4°C is denser than water at 0°C.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Table 1 lists the conditions necessary for a population to remain in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (HWE).

If a gene has 1 dominant allele and 1 recessive allele only, the relative frequencies of these 2 alleles are typically represented by p and q, respectively. For example, if Gene A has 2 alleles (A and a), the relative frequency of A = p and the relative frequency of a = q. For a population in HWE, genotypic relative frequencies then occur shown in Table 2.


Table 3 lists 9 hypothetical populations, 1 gene each population, and some of their allelic and genotypic relative frequencies. Some populations in Table 3 are not in HWE.
questions.question: 29.  The mutations referred to in Condition 3 of Table 1 occur in which of the following types of molecules?

questions.title: Passsage Ⅶ
questions.article:
Introduction

Two solid metal cylinders (X and Y) have the same length and cross-sectional area. Cylinder X is made of hypothetical Metal X, and Cylinder Y is made of hypothetical Metal Y.

Both cylinders are at 25°C. The exterior of each cylinder is insulated everywhere except at one end. Two students are asked the following question: If the 2 cylinders are dropped into a container of boiling water at the same time, the insulated end of which cylinder will reach 50°C first?

Relevant physical properties for Cylinder X and Metal X are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. The value of each physical property for Cylinder X (Metal X) is expressed as a multiple of the value of the same physical property for Cylinder Y (Metal Y).


Each student proposed a different answer to the question they were asked.

Student 1

Because TC of Metal X is 2 times that of Metal Y and the cylinders are the same size, the rate of heat conduction within Cylinder X will be 2 times that within Cylinder Y. Therefore, the rate at which heat flows into Cylinder X will be 2 times the rate at which heat flows into Cylinder Y, and the insulated end of Cylinder X will take half as long as the insulated end of Cylinder Y to reach 50°C.

Student 2

The heat capacity (HC) of each cylinder equals SH of the metal times the mass of the cylinder, so HC of Cylinder X is 4 times HC of Cylinder Y. Thus, to reach 50℃, the insulated end of Cylinder X must absorb 4 times as much heat as the insulated end of Cylinder Y. Because the rate at which heat flows into Cylinder X will be only 2 times that for Cylinder Y, the insulated end of Cylinder X will take 2 times as long to reach 50°C as the insulated end of Cylinder Y.
questions.question: 34.  The immersion of the cylinders in the water will cause the greatest increase in which of the following form of energy within each cylinder?

questions.question: 35.  The insulated end of which cylinder will reach 50°C first, according to Student 1 and Student 2, respectively ?

choices.A: Student 1: Cylinder X         Student 2: Cylinder X
choices.B: Student 1: Cylinder Y         Student 2: Cylinder Y
choices.C: Student 1: Cylinder X         Student 2: Cylinder Y
choices.D: Student 1: Cylinder Y         Student 2: Cylinder X

questions.question: 36.  Based on the Introduction, if SH of Metal X is 0.16 unit, what is SH of Metal Y ?

questions.question: 37.  Based on Student 1's discussion, the rate of heat conduction in an object depends on which of the following quantities?

choices.A: HC of the object and TC of the material making up the object
choices.B: TC of the material making up the object and the dimensions of the object
choices.C: SH and TC of the material making up the object
choices.D: SH of the material making up the object and the mass of the object

questions.question: 40.  Student 1 would hypothesize that if the 2 cylinders were brought to 50°C and then were dropped into ice water, the insulated end of Cylinder X would take half as long as that of Cylinder Y to reach 0°C. Student 1's hypothesis is most likely based on the assumption that:

choices.A: TC for each cylinder is less when the cylinder is cooled than when the cylinder is heated.
choices.B: TC for each cylinder is the same when the cylinder is cooled as when the cylinder is heated.
choices.C: SH for each cylinder is less when the cylinder is cooled than when the cylinder is heated.
choices.D: SH for each cylinder is greater when the cylinder is cooled than when the cylinder is heated.
